awd_titl_txt: Catalog-constrained models of tremor and slow slip
awd_abstract_narration:
About 16 years ago the scientific community became aware of two previously unrecognized styles of fault slip.  It had been thought that faults at depth either spent most of their time locked, slipping only in brief earthquakes, or else crept along steadily at the plate tectonic rate (centimeters per year).  Starting around 2000 it was recognized that along the deep extension of faults in subduction zones, the fault did not simply progress from being locked at shallow depth to creeping at the plate rate at greater depth.  Instead, in this intermediate regime the fault periodically accelerated to slip speeds perhaps 100 times the plate tectonic rate, but then slowed down again without producing earthquakes.  These "episodic slow slip events" were comparable in energy release to magnitude 6.5 earthquakes, but lasted days to weeks rather than several seconds.  In addition, these slow earthquakes (observed geodetically) were accompanied by a new signal seen on seismometers, termed "tectonic tremor".  Tremor consists of myriad "low frequency earthquakes" that correspond in energy release to magnitude 1?2.5 earthquakes, but that last roughly 10 times as long (a few tenths of a second).  Studies of episodic slow slip and tremor are relevant to earthquake hazards because they represent times of increased stressing rate on the shallow, locked portion of subduction zone faults capable of producing magnitude 9 earthquakes. It has also been proposed that the up-dip extent of tremor might be used to assess the down-dip extent of future great earthquakes, with important implications for ground shaking in Seattle. But we need to understand both slow slip and tremor better before we can confidently translate such ideas into statements about seismic risk. The proposed study seeks to improve our understanding of these styles of fault slip.  

When episodic slow slip was first discovered, the question was how faults could spontaneously and periodically accelerate, but then decelerate without producing an earthquake.  Now, the goal is to use observations of slow slip to distinguish between competing hypotheses for this behavior.  For the past several years the researchers have been improving tremor detection/location algorithms, with the aim of generating high-resolution catalogs that expand the observational constraints on slow slip (tremor is useful in this regard because it can be located more accurately than the underlying slow slip).  The goal of this proposal is to develop numerical models of slow slip that use these observational constraints as guides.  Key observations include: (1) Although the main tremor front propagates laterally along the fault at speeds of 5-10 km/day, secondary tremor fronts arise behind the main front that propagate tens to hundreds of times faster. (2) These secondary migrations take the form of rapid tremor reversals, all of which start at the main front and propagate in the opposite direction, or migrations that propagate along the main front independent of the main front orientation.  Some of the largest rapid tremor reversals begin as migrations along the main front.  None of the migrations start at the main front and propagate in the long-term propagation direction. (3) Closest to the main front, the tremor migrations are small and recur on timescales far too short to be tidally driven. As these intervals gradually increase from minutes to hours, eventually the largest rapid tremor reversals become modulated by the 12.4-hour tides.  This work seeks to reproduce these observations using models of rate- and state-dependent friction, including both relatively homogeneous models and those that explicitly include asperities intended to mimic tremor sources.  Emphasis will be placed on understanding analytically why the simulations do what they do, so that their results can be extrapolated beyond the narrow confines of their specific assumptions.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Until recently, it was thought that geologic faults could be grouped into one of two categories:  Those that remain stuck until they slip in brief, but potentially damaging, earthquakes ("stick-slip" behavior), and those that slide continuously at the plate tectonic rate of a few centimeters per year.  About 2 decades ago a third style was seen emanating from the deepest part of subduction zone faults, below the depths of magnitude 9 earthquakes:  Nearly periodic "slow earthquakes", in which the fault accelerates to velocities of roughly 100 times the plate rate, but then decelerates without reaching elastodynamic speeds.  Associated with this geodetically-observed deformation was a previously unknown seismic signal, termed "tectonic tremor".  Tremor is a low-amplitude, quasi-continuous ground motion generated by myriad "low-frequency earthquakes", or LFEs, comparable to magnitude 1-2 earthquakes in size but lasting about 10 times longer.  LFEs also differ from regular earthquakes in exhibiting a narrow range of magnitudes and an even narrower range of durations, given that hundreds of thousands of them have been detected.

Trying to understand the mechanics underlying these new styles of fault slip has occupied seismologists and geophysicists ever since their discovery.  Numerical models of this process are hindered by the lack of reliable constitutive equations for fault slip at these depths, so work funded by this award focused on obtaining higher spatial and temporal resolution of LFEs and tectonic tremor to provide constraints on those models. 

Currently there are two end-member views of what LFEs are.  The first is that they are similar to "repeating earthquakes" on the San Andreas and other faults:  Stick-slipping patches surrounded by a creeping fault, with unchanging boundaries determined by a contrast in material properties.  The second is that they represent just the high-frequency limit of stochastic (to some extent "random") accelerations and decelerations of slip on the fault, with continually-changing boundaries between what is sliding quickly and what is not.  Potential sources for such randomness, as well as the limited range of durations of LFEs, include seismic waves reflected from the boundaries of a low-seismic-velocity fault zone, or shear of a granular layer.  Field observations of fault zones believed to have been eroded from tremor-generating depths (35-45 km) often consist of "brittle" (potentially earthquake-generating) blocks of metamorphosed basalt in a more ductile matrix, offering some support for the granular flow analogy, with the characteristic duration of LFEs being set by the fault zone thickness.  Seismology has given us direct information on the or magnitude or "moment" of LFEs, but not on their physical dimensions; estimates range from about 0.1 to 1 km, the same order of magnitude as the thickness of these eroded fault zones. 

Our previous tremor catalogs are potentially useful for distinguishing between these different hypotheses for what LFEs are, because their location errors are at least modestly smaller than the larger LFE size estimate of 1 km.  Those catalogs are based on 4-second time windows, most of which include multiple (and usually uncountable) LFEs.  The goal of the current work is to maintain to the extent possible small location errors, while increasing the number of detections as close as possible to the maximum feasible of roughly one event per LFE duration (approximately 1/2 second).  Preliminary results suggest that so many close-in-time LFEs occur within 1 km of one another that LFEs are unlikely to represent kilometer-scale fixed asperities that undergo repeated slick-slip failure.  Rather, if they have this large size, they are more likely to result from stochastic accelerations and decelerations of a fault on a characteristic 1/2-second time scale.  If, on the other hand, they are closer to 100 m in size, the question becomes how thousands of them can occur in close proximity without any growing to be much larger in magnitude or duration.

This project led to the training of one graduate student in data analysis, public speaking, teaching, and writing scientific papers.  It will not immediately lead to any reduction in earthquake risk.  In the long term, however, reducing earthquake risk is aided by a better understanding of how faults operate, and this research contributes to that understanding.  To the extent that understanding tremor and low frequency earthquakes requires thinking about deep fault zones as granular layers, this research also forges connections between seismology and previously independent fields in physics, chemical engineering, and industry that are concerned with the flow of granular materials.


Last Modified: 07/10/2022
Modified by: Allan M Rubin
